title: Fetterman to Return to US Senate in April After Hospitalization
description: Senator John Fetterman will return to the US Senate the week of April 17, two months after checking himself into a hospital for depression, according to a person familiar with the Pennsylvania Democrat’s plans.

title: Biden World Bank Pick Poised to Win Job as Sole Expected Nominee
description: Ajay Banga, the US pick to head the World Bank, appears almost certain to become the anti-poverty lender’s next president after nominations closed Wednesday with no country publicly proposing an alternative candidate.

title: Turkey’s Erdogan Blames Rate Hikes for Market Turbulence in West
description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan blamed interest rate increases for the current turmoil in developed markets, saying that monetary tightening risks dragging the global economy into recession.

title: Taiwan Is Pushing Biden for a Tax Deal That Could Infuriate China
description: President Joe Biden wants to bring the world’s most sophisticated chipmakers to the US. Taiwan says he should offer them a better tax deal –- one that could infuriate China.

title: China’s Premier Steps Up Charm Offensive for Wary Foreign Firms
description: Chinese Premier Li Qiang is making another pitch to foreign businesses in a high-profile speech Thursday, seeking to restore global confidence in the world’s No. 2 economy after years of punishing Covid restrictions and escalating US tensions.

title: House Republicans Question US Spending on Ukraine Assistance
description: Congressional Republicans said billions of dollars in US assistance for Ukraine risks being misspent and could be better used for domestic priorities, a fresh sign of the party’s growing ambivalence regarding American support for the war.

title: Trump Fights Order for Testimony of Former White House Officials
description: Former President Donald Trump is appealing an order rejecting his efforts to block grand jury testimony from several former White House advisers in an investigation into efforts to undermine the 2020 presidential election.

title: US Air Force Plans to End Lockheed Hypersonic Weapon Program
description: The Air Force won’t pursue a hypersonic weapons program under development by Lockheed Martin Corp. as officials signal more support for a different initiative by rival Raytheon Corp.

title: Pentagon Says Only Half of Its F-35 Jet Fleet Is Mission-Ready
description: Only about half of the Pentagon’s fleet of F-35 fighter jets are considered mission-capable, well below the target of 65% and a state of readiness the program manager terms “unacceptable.”

title: UAE Ruler Names Son Abu Dhabi Crown Prince, Elevates Other Royals
description: The ruler of the United Arab Emirates elevated his son to crown prince of Abu Dhabi, effectively positioning him as second-in-line in the major OPEC oil exporter in a move that bypassed older and more experienced royals.

title: FDIC Faces $23 Billion in Costs From Bank Failures. It Wants Big Lenders to Pay
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., facing almost $23 billion in costs from recent bank failures, is considering steering a larger-than-usual portion of that burden to the nation’s biggest banks, according to people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Jill Biden Will Attend Vigil for Nashville Shooting Victims
description: First Lady Jill Biden will attend a memorial service on Wednesday evening for the victims of a mass shooting at a Nashville elementary school.

title: Powell Points Republicans to Forecasts Showing One More Hike
description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, asked in a private meeting with US lawmakers how much further the central bank will raise interest rates this year, pointed to policymakers’ latest forecasts showing they anticipate one more increase, according to Republican Representative Kevin Hern.

title: Biden Trails Current GOP Runner-Up DeSantis in 2024 Race
description: President Joe Biden leads Republican frontrunner Donald Trump in a hypothetical 2024 general election matchup, according to a new poll, but trails likely GOP contender Ron DeSantis.

title: FDIC Pressed to Exempt Smaller Banks From Paying for Rescues at SVB, Signature
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. is coming under pressure from lawmakers to exempt community banks from the special fee it’s preparing to charge US lenders to account for its rescue of uninsured depositors at two failed lenders.

title: Scotiabank Economist Excoriates Trudeau, Freeland Over $32 Billion Spending Boost
description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s plan to add billions of dollars in new annual spending has some economists worried that Canada is at risk of racking up unsustainable debt — especially if economic growth comes in worse than expected.

title: LGBTQ Food-Stamp Lawsuit by GOP States Dismissed
description: A Biden administration rule barring states from discriminating against poor LGBTQ people in the distribution of food stamps and other nutrition assistance programs survived a legal challenge by almost two dozen Republican-led states.

title: Turkey Set to Approve Finland’s NATO Membership on Thursday
description: Turkey’s parliament will vote to approve Finland’s membership in NATO on Thursday, following through on President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s promise to let the Nordic nation into the defense alliance.

title: Bolsonaro Returns to Brazil to Take on Lula as Opposition Leader
description: After three months of vacation in Florida, Jair Bolsonaro is expected to finally return to Brazil on Thursday to assume the role of opposition leader and challenge the leftist government of his foe Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva.

title: US Urges EU to Sanction Chinese Satellite Firm Over Russia Aid
description: The US is urging the European Union and other allies to sanction a Chinese satellite company for allegedly supporting Russia’s military operations in Ukraine, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: UK Set to Unveil Programs to Speed Renewables, Capture Carbon
description: The UK will outline plans to speed up the deployment of renewable power and capture carbon emissions from industry as part of a plan to boost investment in British energy security and independence.

title: Germany’s Greens Dealt Setbacks as Coalition Pressure Builds
description: Germany’s Greens suffered back-to-back defeats this week at the hands of their two partners in the ruling coalition, giving ground on climate-protection measures and agreeing to a possible exception to the European Union’s proposed combustion-engine ban.

title: Biden Begins Oil Drilling-Rights Sale in Fresh Blow to Activists
description: The Biden administration is auctioning off oil-drilling rights in the Gulf of Mexico, a fresh affront to climate activists still smarting from the White House’s approval of an Arctic exploration project.

title: Swiss Government Sends Credit Suisse Plan to Parliament
description: Switzerland’s government has sent the 109 billion-franc ($118 billion) state guarantees for UBS Group AG’s takeover of Credit Suisse Group AG to the country’s parliament for further debate.

title: US Regulators Face Tough Questions on SVB, Signature Bank Failures
description: The Federal Reserve’s top bank regulator on Wednesday said that supervisors could have done more to keep tabs on Silicon Valley Bank before it collapsed earlier this month.

title: Pope Hospitalized for Pulmonary Infection, Vatican Says
description: Francis, 86, does not have Covid-19, but requires several days of therapy.

title: Starbucks Handles Union Talks In ‘Good Faith,’ Howard Schultz Will Testify at Senate Today
description: Starbucks Corp.’s newly departed chief executive officer, Howard Schultz, plans to tell Congress Wednesday that the coffee chain has bargained in good faith with the group that organized hundreds of its stores as the company defends itself against accusations of union busting.

title: Czechs Protest Against Pension Revamp by Cost-Cutting Government
description: Thousands of Czechs took to the streets to protest against planned changes to the pension system that may include raising the retirement age to rein in budget spending.

title: Erdogan Vows New Minimum Wage Hike in Latest Cost-of-Living Appeal
description: Turkey will hike its minimum wage in July, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said, in his latest financial appeal to voters ahead of elections.

title: US, Israel Clash Over Policy That Sparked Democratic Protests
description: The US and Israel clashed after President Joe Biden rebuked Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s administration for its efforts to weaken the judiciary — a policy that’s ignited waves of protests and labor strikes.

title: Germany Boosts Military Support for Ukraine by €12 Billion
description: The German government plans to increase its financial support for Kyiv by as much as €12 billion ($13 billion) to help arm Ukraine in its fight against Russia, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Immigration Minister Confirms Plans to House Asylum Seekers at Former Military Bases
description: Immigration minister Robert Jenrick has confirmed plans to house "several thousand" asylum seekers at former military bases in Essex and Lincolnshire and a separate site in East Sussex.

title: EU Aims to Boost Russia Sanctions Enforcement With New Project
description: The European Union is planning to launch a project with nine member states to identify gaps in the sanctions regime against Russia and to improve coordination between national authorities when enforcing penalties, EU officials said.

title: UK Minister Hopeful That UK and EU Will Soon Move Ahead With Post-Brexit Financial Rules
description: UK Treasury minister John Glen has said he is optimistic that the UK and European Union will soon formalize a pledge to work together on setting rules for banks and financial markets.

title: Phosphate Giant’s Blowout Earnings Give Morocco Welcome Buffer
description: Morocco’s government will get a windfall of about $750 million from dividends this year after state-owned phosphates giant OCP SA reported record earnings, a welcome boost for the kingdom that’s wrestling with stubbornly high inflation and periodic drought.

title: UK Plan to Put Migrants on Ships Rejected as Too Costly in 2022
description: UK officials warned last year that plans to detain asylum seekers on cruise ships and barges could end up being more expensive than housing them in hotels.

title: Erdogan’s Election Headache Grows as Allies Clash on Candidates
description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s fledgling electoral alliance is fraying over a dispute about parliamentary candidates that could threaten his two decades of control with elections just six weeks away.

title: Yellen Says International Aid Programs Crucial to US Leadership
description: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the Biden administration’s proposed spending on international aid and investment programs, exemplified by assistance for Ukraine, would strengthen Washington’s leadership abroad and advance US security interests.

title: A New Test for Xi Over US Ties With Taiwan
description: China predictably warned of unspecified retaliation if Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen meets US House Speaker Kevin McCarthy in the US. But Beijing has some good reasons to act with more restraint than it did last year.

title: US and EU Near Critical Minerals Accord to Unlock US Subsidies
description: The European Union and the US are nearing an agreement on critical minerals that would provide EU companies access to some of the massive green subsidies offered in President Joe Biden’s Inflation Reduction Act.

title: Kim’s Rare Display of Nuclear Warheads Sends Chilling Message
description: While the US has long demanded North Korea give up its nuclear weapons, the regime’s biggest display of warheads let the world know that Kim Jong Un has no intention of abandoning his atomic arsenal.

title: Zimbabwe’s Increasingly Powerful Finance Chief Set to Retain Post After Election
description: Zimbabwean Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube secured the ruling party’s endorsement to stand as a lawmaker in upcoming elections, a possible precursor to his reappointment in the next administration.

title: Post-Coup Plan Puts Spotlight on Sudan Army’s Economic Empire
description: Sudan’s army and civilian politicians are discussing a potential power-sharing plan that would curb the military’s dominance of the economy and give regional lawmakers the right to veto mooted projects such as a Russian naval base.

title: DeSantis Fights for Everglades As He Neglects Climate Crisis
description: Picking environmental fights has paid off for Florida’s governor, who built a 2024 base with a unique mix of crusading for wetlands conservation and attacking ESG.

title: India Parliament Lower House Approves Antitrust Law Revamp
description: India moved a step closer to empowering its antitrust watchdog to vet overseas mergers and acquisitions, tightening Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s regulatory grip over how Big Tech firms operate in the country.

title: Modi’s BJP Faces Close Fight in India’s Swing State Karnataka
description: India will hold elections in the populous southern state of Karnataka in May, the results of which will indicate whether the opposition has cut into the popularity of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s ruling party ahead of general elections next year.

title: Swedes’ Support for Nuclear Power Hits Highest Since Fukushima
description: The attitude among Swedes toward nuclear is now the most positive since 2011, the year of the disaster at the Fukushima power plant in Japan.

title: Ukraine Latest: Zelenskiy Warns of Dangers of Bakhmut Defeat
description: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy warned that unless his country wins a drawn-out battle for the key eastern city of Bakhmut, Russia could begin building international support for a deal that would require Ukraine to make unacceptable compromises.

title: Any Russian victory could be perilous: Ukraine’s Zelenskyy
description: ON A TRAIN FROM SUMY TO KYIV, Ukraine (AP) — Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned Tuesday that unless his nation wins a drawn-out battle in a key eastern city, Russia could begin building international support for a deal that could require Ukraine to make unacceptable compromises. He also invited the leader of China, long aligned with Russia, to visit.

title: Any Russian victory could be perilous: Ukraine’s Zelenskyy
description: ON A TRAIN FROM SUMY TO KYIV, Ukraine (AP) — Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy warned Tuesday that unless his nation wins a drawn-out battle in a key eastern city, Russia could begin building international support for a deal that could require Ukraine to make unacceptable compromises. He also invited the leader of China, long aligned with Russia, to visit.

title: Macron’s Allies Fear Street Violence Is Spiraling Out of Control
description: Lawmakers in Macron’s coalition are still backing the reform, but several of them are urging the president to find a way to take the heat out of demonstrations

title: CEOs Have a Poor View of Britain, Says Pharma Lobby Boss
description: Britain’s ambition to become a “science superpower” will fail unless the government reverses the country’s reputation as a poor place to invest, the head of the UK’s biggest pharmaceutical lobby group has warned.

title: Putin’s War Is Intensifying Labor Shortages in Russia’s Economy
description: President Vladimir Putin’s drive to expand Russia’s armed forces is adding to labor shortages as his war in Ukraine draws hundreds of thousands of workers into the military from other sectors of the economy.

title: China Warns Taiwan Leader to Avoid McCarthy as She Visits US
description: China warned the US and Taiwan President Tsai Ing-wen that any meeting between her and House Speaker Kevin McCarthy would be a serious provocation, raising the stakes for her trip to the US.

title: Peru Prosecutors Probe President for Alleged Money Laundering
description: Peruvian prosecutors said late on Tuesday that they had opened an investigation against President Dina Boluarte and former President Pedro Castillo for allegedly laundering money as part of a criminal organization.

title: Japan Foreign Minister Set for First Visit to China Since 2019
description: Japan’s foreign minister is planning to visit China this weekend in the first such trip in about three years, Kyodo News and other local media reported, as Asia’s two largest economies seek to maintain stable ties amid rising tensions.
